IP2026030_syn_2:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: [REDACTED], a 66-year-old gentleman with severe heterogeneous emphysema characterized by marked left upper lobe hyperinflation, presented for elective bronchoscopic lung volume reduction. Preoperative evaluation revealed an intact left oblique fissure and quantitative perfusion demonstrating preservation of the contralateral lung.
OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: Following the induction of general anesthesia and placement of an 8.0 mm endotracheal tube, the airway was examined. The left bronchial tree was systematically interrogated. A Chartis balloon catheter assessment of the LUL bronchus yielded a CV-negative phenotype (rapid flow decay to zero). Consequently, four Zephyr endobronchial valves were sequentially deployed into the apicoposterior, anterior, and lingular segments. Post-deployment inspection confirmed complete lobar occlusion. Immediate physiological response was noted via improved excursion of the left hemidiaphragm.
IMPRESSION: Successful LUL BLVR. The patient remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the step-down unit for close pneumothorax surveillance.
IP2026030_syn_3:
Procedure Justification: Bronchoscopy for lung volume reduction (CPT 31647).
Technique:
1. Access: Flexible bronchoscope introduced through ETT.
2. Assessment: Chartis catheter inserted into LUL bronchus. Balloon inflated to occlude bronchus. Flow measurements recorded showing absence of collateral ventilation (necessary condition for valve efficacy).
3. Deployment: Delivery catheter passed through working channel. Four (4) distinct Zephyr valves were sized and deployed into the specific segmental bronchi of the Left Upper Lobe.
4. Verification: Visual confirmation of valve seating and fluoroscopic confirmation of position performed.
Outcome: Total occlusion of the target lobe achieved. Codes support single lobe treatment with assessment.

IP2026030:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with endobronchial valve placement, left upper lobe.
Patient: [REDACTED], 67-year-old male with severe heterogeneous emphysema and hyperinflation despite maximal medical therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0 mm ETT).
Indication: Symptomatic severe COPD/emphysema with upper-lobeâ€“predominant disease and hyperinflation, candidate for bronchoscopic lung volume reduction.
Pre-procedure imaging and physiology: High-resolution CT with severe LUL-predominant emphysema and intact left oblique fissure (>95% completeness). Quantitative perfusion with relatively preserved perfusion to contralateral lung. Baseline FEV1 32% predicted, RV 210% predicted.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis balloon catheter deployed in the left upper lobe bronchus showed rapid flow decay to zero with plateau, consistent with absence of collateral ventilation.
Procedure details: Under general anesthesia, a therapeutic flexible bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT. The left bronchial tree was inspected and the LUL bronchus id[REDACTED]. Chartis measurements were obtained as above. A delivery catheter was then advanced, and four Zephyr endobronchial valves were placed sequentially in the apicoposterior, anterior, and lingular segmental bronchi to completely occlude the LUL. Valve positions were confirmed bronchoscopically and with fluoroscopy. After several minutes, there was visible reduction in LUL ventilation with improved excursion of the left hemidiaphragm.
Complications: Minimal self-limited oozing at one segmental orifice controlled with cold saline. No hypoxemia, hemodynamic instability, or immediate pneumothorax.
Disposition: Extubated in the bronchoscopy suite and transferred to step-down unit for post-BLVR monitoring with serial CXRs and telemetry.
Plan: Monitor for post-procedure pneumothorax for at least 72 hours. Continue bronchodilators and pulmonary rehab. Repeat spirometry and 6MWT at 3 months to assess response.
